summary:
"Don't work for daily bread, Just work for sustainability (Uwitonze, 2021)".

My name is Narcisse Uwitonze, I was born in Rwanda; a small, developing, and densely populated country with rich biodiversity. Since I was a boy, I have observed the great loss of natural ecosystems due to poor and intensive farming practices. Today I am part of a growing number of young conservationists who realize that our future and economy depend on maintaining our natural resources. Wageningen University, the University of Rwanda, and the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International have provided me with opportunities for learning hands-on conservation biology applications.

To date, the state of biodiversity is deteriorating globally due to increasing human pressure and insufficient conservation responses. This tremendous species decline is associated with rapid urbanization and human population growth. Biodiversity continues to decline, with ongoing losses of species and habitats. This biodiversity decline is due to deforestation and landscape degradation. At the top of such tragic biodiversity loss, there are enormous negative impacts of climate change on species and landscapes like unpredicted wildfires and severe droughts.

I am a quick learner and always strive for excellence. My motivations are always encircled in my motto” Don’t work for daily bread, just work for Sustainability”. I am open to a new challenging position as it is the only way to develop as a scientist. I am the perfect person to get a group project rolling, but I also know how to sit back and let others take the lead. My cheerful nature and openness to feedback mean I am always learning and growing as a learner, a strength that will continue to serve in college and beyond.

profile_positions.description:
During my second year of my Master's program. I applied For an MSc thesis opportunity in the Forest Ecology and Forest Management Group of Wageningen University in the Department of Environmental Sciences. Below is a short summary of the project:

Seed rain dynamics are an important factor to understand secondary forest regeneration. The aim of this research was to determine the extent to which the plant reproductive strategies and environmental factors play a role in seed rain dynamics of lowland wet tropical rain forest. This study was carried out in a wet tropical forest landscape in Chiapas, southern Mexico. The seed rain has been collected twice a month in seven sites through established seed traps, and the environmental variables have been monthly recorded for five years from 2002-to 2006. The results showed that species identified in the seed rain have various reproductive strategies. About 72% of the species are supra-annual species (i.e they produce seeds less than once per year). Also, most of the species (67%) are aseasonal species as they can produce seeds in both dry and wet seasons. Seasonality-based reproductive strategies (dry and wet) do not differ in terms of seed rain abundance and biomass. However, the increase in temperature has a negative effect on the supra-annual species by reducing the flowering frequency. Thus, as supra-annual species dominated the Chiapas landscape, the landscape will be negatively affected by the increase in temperature. For landscape restoration, these findings call up on conservation managers to select species in annual and seasonal reproductive strategies in restoration projects.
profile_positions.title: Thesis work: Understanding plant reproductive strategies of wet tropical Forest, Mexico

profile_positions.description:
Participating in a project with Albertine Rift Conservation Society (ARCOS Network), It was about the Ecological Integrity Assessment of all wetlands in Rwanda, the project implemented through the grant from the JRS Biodiversity Foundation. 
My tasks were as follow:

+Developing methodologies for biodiversity collection specifically plant methodologies.
+Plant survey and collection using herbarium techniques
+Analyzing both qualitative and quantitative data to provide concrete results to the JRS biodiversity foundation
+Drafting the plant list needed for wetland restoration in Kigali city
+Data analysis to using various statistical software
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Implementing a project on which I won a grant (Young Explorer Grant) in August 2017 from the National Geographic Society to carry out the project (Regeneration time of key gorilla food plants and its implication to mountain gorilla conservation), within the collaboration of myself (Principal Investigator) and Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International/ Karisoke Research Center.  

My tasks were as follow:

+Managing all activities related to the project
+Writing and refining the methodology section
+Performing and managing the data collection activities and processing
+Making Gorilla food regeneration database
+Writing the final report to the National Geographic Society
+Ongoing work manuscript to be published in peer reviewed journal

My former students are now occupying different positions ranging from entrepreneurs to educators in Rwanda and abroad.
